Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a High-Temperature X-ray Diffraction System - Transforming Materials Science and Culture in West Texas

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) award supports the acquisition of a High-Temperature X-Ray Diffraction System (XRD) at West Texas A&M University (WTAMU) for potentially transformative fundamental research on nanotechnology and resilient building materials. The XRD allows researchers to investigate material properties under controlled temperature and pressure conditions, making it a critical tool for developing new materials, increasing the lifespan of materials, and improving production processes. The research team includes female and African American faculty and researchers from mechanical engineering, materials science and civil engineering. The instrumentation also provides broad educational opportunities for a regional, emerging Hispanic Serving Institution (HSI), enabling over 1500 K-12 and higher education students to have a research or laboratory experience with the XRD.

The XRD has unique capabilities that will enable fundamental research on nanoaluminum, nanodiamonds, and resilient materials and infrastructure. Researchers will measure stress states at the nanoscale to determine how manipulation affects particle reactivity. This knowledge may lead to advances in nano aluminum energy storage capabilities. The XRD will be used in-situ to study the high bond energy of the nano-sized diamond and the effect of its highly functional surface when used as an additive in metallic mixtures. These alloys may enable advances in aerospace applications, where weight and temperature resistance are vital, and may hold promise for prosthetics and implant technology. The XRD probes atomic distances and provides information aabout material properties at the microscale. By analyzing structures with different materials both before and after damage, it is possible to estimate wind loads, ground accelerations and blast intensities that they can withstand. This knowledge enables the development of structural materials optimized for use in areas with a high probability of natural or man-made hazards.

POR.DRECONTENT:
West Texas A&M University received funding for a High-Temperature X-Ray Diffraction System (HT-XRD). The instrument has been installed in a core laboratory space allowing access to all researchers at the university. With undergraduate engineering programs growing in enrollment at an average of 15% each year and the addition of a new Master’s program in engineering, which will be the only engineering program at the graduate level within a 100-mile radius of the university, new research and teaching opportunities are rapidly developing. Faculty and student research in engineering is progressing due to this new and local ability to perform crystallographic and elemental analysis at the nano- and micro-scale.

The new XRD is significantly advancing projects across several fields of materials science spanning from novel nanomaterials development and characterization to the study of materials exposed to extreme stresses such as weather events and earthquakes. The addition of the HT-XRD is enabling a host of new research activities that will contribute to the evolution of scientific  knowledge in a number of areas with the initial research focusing on these projects:.

  • Measurements of a fundamental mechanical property of aluminum particles (i.e., stress state) and assessment of how manipulation of this property affects overall particle reactivity. Preliminary evidence suggests that manipulating stresses and surface chemistry will significantly affect reactivity and reaction mechanism. The XRD is the only technology that can measure this stress state at the nano-scale Al. If successful, this work will advance the development of energetic material science for energy storage and munition design.
  • Examination of the high-energy (strong) bonds holding together nano-diamond (the hardest known material which has been shown to exhibit enhanced characteristic behaviors due to high surface area). The HT-XRD is currently being used in-situ to study the high bond energy of the nano-sized diamond by using it as an additive in traditional thermite and explosive mixtures. This work is yielding novel superalloys with enhanced mechanical and thermal properties.
  • Determination of the material properties of structures subject to extreme loads.  By analyzing damage to structures, it is possible to estimate wind loads, ground accelerations, and blast intensities, as the material properties can also be accurately determined. The XRD is needed in order to generate research data to gain fundamental understanding at the micro-scale of these damaged materials’ properties. Analysis of this data will result in structural materials optimized for use in structures located in areas with a high probability of such extreme events.

The research accomplished with the XRD instrument is providing important and necessary benefits to society, supporting nanotechnology advancement, development of improved structural materials and broad educational opportunities for a regional, emerging Hispanic Serving Institution (HSI) and an emerging, highly-anticipated graduate program in engineering. The results of the proposed research on nanomaterials may lead to the development of materials that will form the basis for new, highly-specific technologies geared toward national defense. The results of the proposed research on nano-diamonds are already yielding the creation of a new class of incredibly strong superalloys that could be used for energetic formulations or for structural properties, thereby improving the performance and accessibility of nanotechnology-inspired materials. Studying materials that undergo extreme loading events will realize new and/or engineered materials that are capable of withstanding unwanted but dangerous extreme events such as hurricanes and tornadoes.

In addition to the direct, tangible benefits of the research itself, this project is alread having a strong impact on the research and education communities associated with WTAMU enabling over 1500 K-12  and higher education students to have a research or laboratory experience with the XRD. The addition and use of this state-of-the-art HT-XRD will greatly enhance WTAMU’s capabilities and improve the university's ability to impact quality education, outreach, and research.
